headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Porter
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Porter, head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome. As always, we thank you for your interest in Williams. As you know, yesterday afternoon we released our financial results and posted several important items on our website, williams.com. These items include the press release of
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome. As always, we thank you for your interest in Williams. As you know, yesterday afternoon we released our financial results and posted several important items on our website, williams.com. These items include the press release of our results with related schedules and our analyst package; a presentation on our results and growth opportunities with related audio commentary from our President and CEO, Alan Armstrong; and an update to our quarterly data book, which contains detailed information regarding various aspects of our business.
This morning, Alan will make a few brief comments, and then we will open the discussion up for Q&A. Rory Miller is here from our Midstream business; Randy Barnard is here from our Gas Pipeline business; and our CFO, Don Chappel, is also available to respond to any questions.
In yesterday's presentation and also in the quarterly data book, you will find an important disclaimer related to forward-looking statements. This disclaimer is important and integral to all of our remarks and you should review it. Also included in our presentation materials are various non-GAAP measures that have been reconciled back to generally excepted accounting principles. Those reconciliation schedules appear at the back of the presentation materials.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. First, let me wish everyone who has been affected the Hurricane Sandy the best of luck in the recovery. As you know, given the significant disruption that occurred to the normal market activity, we decided to dela
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. First, let me wish everyone who has been affected the Hurricane Sandy the best of luck in the recovery. As you know, given the significant disruption that occurred to the normal market activity, we decided to delay our earnings release webcast by a day. We also know this concentrated a number of earnings calls today, so thanks a bunch for joining us this morning for this webcast amongst a very busy morning. Hopefully, you had a chance to listen to my prerecorded comments released yesterday afternoon. But just in case you didn't, I'll quickly hit on some key things and then we'll move on to our Q&A session.
We have several really important items to communicate to this week starting with of course a review of our third quarter performance. So I'll quickly touch on the key things from that discussion. 
For the third quarter, WMB's adjusted income was up about 17% over second quarter in spite of NGL fracs  spread that were about 18% lower on average than the already low second quarter amounts and the impact of hurricane Isaac, and I'll talk about that just a little bit. With regard to the NGL fracs spread, we saw about a 9% lower average NGL composite price, but an even higher impact from natural gas strength prices that were up about 26% on average. So certainly the frac spread environment that we saw on the third quarter continued to find from what was a heavy decline from first quarter to second quarter, and so we will not expect in that degree of decline into the third quarter. And again, a lot of that was impacted by gas prices moving up. 
Turning to fee-based revenues now for third quarter, this measure grew about 5% per year over year for the third quarter. And importantly, at the Midstream segment for WPZ, these grew at about 12% rate. So continued great volume growth there in our fee-based revenues, and just to a highlight a few of the areas that affected that, our gathering volumes in the business, such as our natural gas gathering volumes in the Midstream business were up 17% higher from 3Q '11 to 3Q '12. And in the eastern onshore which is basically our Marcellus area and -- which is in the western Gulf of Mexico, we saw both of those areas gathering volumes actually double from year to year.
The main driver of the 12% growth rate for overall for our business was eastern GMP business, as I mentioned, and of course, one of the drivers there was the acquisition from the Cayman, which we now refer to as the hot Ohio power Midstream in our business, and that was about $30 million between years. 
Also, there was a couple of factors that brought that 12% growth rate down and tend to lessen it. The Hurricane Isaac reduced some of our Gulf Coast fee-based revenues and in third quarter of '11, we actually had pretty significant content settlements related to some of our nor tape business. So on a normalized basis, we see these fee-based revenues actually growing even stronger than the 12% for WPZ Midstream. Most of the Hurricane Isaac impacts were cost by interruptions and third-party operations. So while we did have some immediate interruption in our offshore assets in particular, in terms of getting things back up and running, it really was due to some downstream oil terminals and some downstream NGL pipeline held us up a little bit longer. So we really did fair pretty well against our assets that there were some assets that were integrated with a little more challenge.
Hurricane Isaac also significantly impacted our results in the Midstream Canadian and all defense business as an Geismar had downtime that affected its production volumes, as well as some damage to a furnace as we try to restart the plant after the hurricane. So all in, this affected our segment profitability from about $9 million to $13 million, and about $4 million of this was for adjusted settlement profit.
So that's a quick look up our third quarter drivers, but again, given continued lower NGL commodity price environment and the Hurricane Isaac impact, we actually had a pretty good operational period here for the third quarter.
So next up, we have some important updates to our guidance for '13 and '14, from both WMB and WPZ. Included in these updates are the effect of the Geismar drop-down, which we've announced will be closing very soon, but we've also got some other adjustments including somewhat lower revenue growth rates assumptions for WPZ, and these are really being driven by prolonged natural gas prices assumptions and some of the producers' reactions that we're seeing to that as we go through our September planning process where we've taken a lot of the input from a lot of our producers around our systems. And I certainly want to let you know this really is across the board that we're seeing this in areas that whether we may -- whether producer themselves is heavily impacted by the gas prices. So some examples of that will be areas where we hold the people rights for natural gas drilling operations, and so the producers are not enjoying any of the uplift from the NGLs. And so of course, they're responding to lower natural gas prices, those of course, will be mostly out West where that occurred. We also had some respondents in the Gulf Coast, and then to some degree in the Northeast. But we'll get into a little bit the Northeast. The good news, I would say, in the Northeast is that the activities continue there. And for the most part, the activities, particularly in Ohio Valley Midstream area, really have nothing to do with either prices or with the drilling that results from the resources. Actually those are coming in a little better than we thought. It just really the way in terms of the activities in our ability to that infrastructure into place there quickly. So all in all, I would say the environment's pretty good, but I do think with our gas prices at $3.25, it's in our assumptions and planning around that we do expect continued reduction in areas that are totally dependent on just the natural gas price.
So I do want to reaffirm our plans for strong cash dividend growth where we're expecting a 55% higher dividend in 2012,at WMB and as well 12% growth in 2013 and 2014 which will move our dividend to $1.20, $1.44 and $1.55, respectively. Our stated policy of paying out WMB dividends for all of the distributions, WMB receives from WPZ less taxes, corporate interests and corporate CapEx. However, we also want investors to appreciate how committed we are sustaining the great strength of WPZ for the long run, and of course, that's what the Geismar drop-down is all about. And it really shows the evidence of WMB's commitment keeping WPZ healthy and making sure that the commodity hedge, the national hedge there is shared with WPZ and not just held with the WMB level. So in that transaction, WMB is receiving nearly $43 million new WPZ LP units related to the Geismar drop-down. Assuming the strong WPZ cash distribution growth rate included in our guidance, WMB will see a significant increase in cash distributions for WPZ. This could result, of course, in an ultimately higher dividend growth rate from what we have forecasted right now for WMB, and certainly, if the forecasted pricing environment that we have out there particularly around ethylene prices occurs, then we would certainly be in a position to further increase the dividend at WMB. So a lot of questions around that as a lot of people snap to the fact that cash distribution will go up significantly from that, and we've certainly been clear that we tend to maintain the policy. And I think our response to that, and we certainly agree with that calculation, but we do have quite a bit of risk embedded in the pricing at WPZ. And so we don't really want to go out any further on that distribution being 2 years ahead of time in terms of the dividend at WMB. I do think we intend to be very sure and really work hard to maintain that the distribution growth rates at WPZ. However, and some of the activities -- some of the things that we might respond to if we did see a commodity collapse, it would pull us down, pull the coverage down of course, would be our ability to impact the GP IDRs that we receive. So we remain very committed to WPZ and help the WPZ and we think we've got a great model. And certainly, if the pricing environment occurs, we're going to be in great shape to continue to increase that dividend at WMB even further.
Of course, at the same time WMB will no longer enjoy 100% of the cash flow and earnings it enjoys today, and as a result, you've seen a lowering of WMB's income guidance related to the noncontrolling interest that arises in Geismer once it's dropped into WPZ. So even though the cash flow piece of that looks stronger, particularly with the capital burden being shifted over to WPZ, the earnings piece of that gets diluted by the issuance of -- to the WPZ LP unit holders. 
Additionally, as I previously mentioned, we have some other updates our guidance for '13 and '14, including lower revenue growth rates across most of our operating areas that are exposed to natural gas prices, as I mentioned. And although we have some fairly low natural gas price assumptions in place for '13 and '14, you really should not misconstrue that we have a lack of confidence in the natural gas market. And in fact, I would tell you we're fairly bullish about the long-term demand that we continue to see built for natural gas, but we've also been impressed with the capabilities of natural gas producers here in the U.S. to continue to lower their cost of production. And so we're balancing that. We do think it will take some time for a lot of the big capital that's coming on to build that demand. But long term, I would tell you we're very bullish on seeing this natural gas market continue to expand.
'S finally, in the prerecorded podcast, we provided additional information about exciting new development in our Canadian and petchem services businesses and update on all of our in guidance projects, most of which are fee-based that really continued to demonstrate how Williams is particularly position to take advantage of this long-term super cycle as a trusted name in the development, construction and operation of exactly the types of infrastructure needed to realize the full potential for producers and end uses of natural gas, NGLs and all of them. So with that, I'll open it up for questions.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Faisel Khan with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Faisel Khan with Citigroup.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just want to understand a little bit more, if you could, and I have a follow-up question. But on the guidance, it seems the commodity price assumptions are roughly the same from the last time you issued guidance. And so, the decrease in earnings seems l
componenttext: I just want to understand a little bit more, if you could, and I have a follow-up question. But on the guidance, it seems the commodity price assumptions are roughly the same from the last time you issued guidance. And so, the decrease in earnings seems like a meaningful decrease in volumes. Can you elaborate a little bit more on what the volume decrease you expect in '14 versus your previous guidance, and I understand it's because of low natural gas prices.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And I would just say really what we saw again, our planning process works is that we start to pull that together in September, and we take in input from all across our systems from producers planned capital for the following year. Of course, it's i
componenttext: Right. And I would just say really what we saw again, our planning process works is that we start to pull that together in September, and we take in input from all across our systems from producers planned capital for the following year. Of course, it's in their best interest to have us educated other plans as well because we've got to go build a lot of the infrastructure for those volumes. And so we've been going through that process in September and I would just tell you that it really across the board. And I would tell you if we thought the spreads were going to be $4.50 or $5, in '13 and -- we probably would have had a different perspective on that. But with our assumption of gas prices being at $3.25 for '13, with that assumption embedded, we have a hard time being more bullish than producers in terms of their capital plans and so we really basically took the capital plan from producers. Now remember, this was a lot of their ideas, of course, were formed over the summer when gas prices were even softer. So if we do see gas prices rebound, we probably would see some more activity and more rigs pick up. But of course, then we would have to raise our gas natural price if we believe that the and that, of course, will come out of the margin for both the NGLs and the all offense margin. So I think there's a pretty good balance there. But in general, I would tell you that we gather a lot of gas, and there's just a lot of areas that are exposed to natural gas prices and we're seeing drops in really all of our regions from what we had forecasted earlier in the year based on producers forecast that we would have picked up in the first part of 2012.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And on the all defense business, the chemicals business, how are you guys thinking about the distributions at WPZ once you drop these assets in? I mean, will some of the distribution be a little bit more of a variable rate? Or if we hav
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And on the all defense business, the chemicals business, how are you guys thinking about the distributions at WPZ once you drop these assets in? I mean, will some of the distribution be a little bit more of a variable rate? Or if we have some base level of free cash flow is that we distributed to unit holders and then the rest will be kind of discretionary sort of use of capital, how are you guys thinking about the cyclical business within WPZ?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great question. And I would say that we do feel like we will need to maintain a coverage ratio there. Of course, one of the things that heavily impacting our coverage ratio at PZ right now is the amount of growth and the amount of equity that we issued he
componenttext: Great question. And I would say that we do feel like we will need to maintain a coverage ratio there. Of course, one of the things that heavily impacting our coverage ratio at PZ right now is the amount of growth and the amount of equity that we issued here in 2012. And so I would say that in a more normal environment with not quite so much leverage to grow in that balance sheet, that we would expect to be seeing higher coverage ratio despite even these lower NGL prices that we saw here in the third quarter. So bottom line is, we intend to maintain a coverage ratio there at WPZ and try to let this swings. Good news is there's a lot of cash flow in WPZ, and we would expect to let that coverage absorb a lot of those swings. If that wasn't enough to absorb that, and then a next move in more dire environment would be to waive some of the GPI DR, if necessary to maintain WPZ's health.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Bradley Olsen from Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Bradley Olsen from Tudor, Pickering.

componenttext: Just a follow up on question about the volume growth assumptions that go into your guidance. How -- you mentioned kind of your broadly lower gas volumes across geographies. Would you say that this volume change is enough to impact your longer-term 5 Bcf a day estimate in terms of gas that you handle in the Marcellus?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012

componenttext: It certainly could. And in some areas, I would tell you the areas that are -- the dryer gas are most likely to be the larger part of that impact. On OBM, I would say there might be some delays there, but currently we're actually increasing that a little bit above in the near term from what we had in our September -- sorry, in our June forecast for that. So it's really those areas that are just dependent on dry gas volumes and OBM, I would say, to a degree that is lowered a little bit, that's going to be from just delays in getting the infrastructure in the drilling activity occurring there. But we certainly are very excited about what we continue to see in the OBM area in terms of the producers economics and their activities and the resource there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as far in the Midstream side of the business at WPZ, it looked like the OpEx, which had ticked up in the second quarter, was kind of flat sequentially. And I was wondering if there are items in there are which are transitory in nature or
componenttext: Okay, great. And as far in the Midstream side of the business at WPZ, it looked like the OpEx, which had ticked up in the second quarter, was kind of flat sequentially. And I was wondering if there are items in there are which are transitory in nature or whether we're looking at maybe kind of higher go forward operating cost in that business?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Rory. I'd say for the near term across Midstream on operating expenses, we're probably pretty flat with '12. And so in terms of thinking about run rate, and that's probably a comment that I'm making for '13, but we're expecting to be fairly flat w
componenttext: This is Rory. I'd say for the near term across Midstream on operating expenses, we're probably pretty flat with '12. And so in terms of thinking about run rate, and that's probably a comment that I'm making for '13, but we're expecting to be fairly flat with '12 for '13, and then after there maybe some growth.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just one last question. I realize that some of the petrochemical pipelines are making their way down the PZ in conjunction with the Geismar drop-down. But are there additional assets as part of this Exxon asset package that you have acqui
componenttext: Okay, great. And just one last question. I realize that some of the petrochemical pipelines are making their way down the PZ in conjunction with the Geismar drop-down. But are there additional assets as part of this Exxon asset package that you have acquired which will remain at WMB for the time being, and maybe if you could just give a breakdown of what percentage of those assets sits at PZ versus MB, that'll be great.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Don. I could just mention that the assets that we announced, the petrochemical assets we acquired from Exxon will be at the Williams level for the time being. We felt that Williams had poor financial capacity to hold those assets while being devel
componenttext: This is Don. I could just mention that the assets that we announced, the petrochemical assets we acquired from Exxon will be at the Williams level for the time being. We felt that Williams had poor financial capacity to hold those assets while being developed than PZ did given all rated be larger array of growth opportunities that PZ was holding. So that was the primary reason we -- the Williams WPZ. But that remains a drop-down opportunity that PZ will likely enjoy in the future day.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ted Durban from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ted Durban from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're just think about the commodity exposure at the WMB level, and the increased investments in Canada. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about the mix of maybe adding more commodities with those additional investments rather than and kind of how yo
componenttext: We're just think about the commodity exposure at the WMB level, and the increased investments in Canada. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about the mix of maybe adding more commodities with those additional investments rather than and kind of how you're thinking about the cash otherwise tax issues bringing it back and maybe that's part of the reason why you're driving more investments in Canada?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Don again. I would say that again for us to bring back $500 million of cash tax rate to be about 50%, so about $250 million of that would be paid to the IRS, that's pretty a lot of value acreage. And the good news is we have some opportunities in
componenttext: This is Don again. I would say that again for us to bring back $500 million of cash tax rate to be about 50%, so about $250 million of that would be paid to the IRS, that's pretty a lot of value acreage. And the good news is we have some opportunities in Canada that we think are very strong with very high rates of returns, so if you look at that versus the opportunities here in the U.S., we just see despite the fact that some commodity volatilities we just have higher hurdle rate on those projects such that even in the low commodity price environment, there's still very attractive investments and in a more than expected case, it's very strong. And when you compare that to paying all that cash tax and bringing it back and investing in an opportunity here in the U.S., the Canadian investment despite the fact that it's commodity sensitive business tends to be something that we're interested in. I think the one area that we're exploring is PDH, and we think that propping intended is going to be under tremendous pressure in the margins of that business will likely be very strong.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would add to that, this is Alan. I would add to that as well, that the teams in CNRL, ethane contract that supports it does have a 4 for the ethane, that's the cost of service pricing for the ethane. So there is some contractual support for that risk th
componenttext: I would add to that, this is Alan. I would add to that as well, that the teams in CNRL, ethane contract that supports it does have a 4 for the ethane, that's the cost of service pricing for the ethane. So there is some contractual support for that risk that we're taking in that expansion out there. For both the new ethane capital that we're investing, as well as the CNRL expansion.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012

componenttext: Great. Got it. That's great. And can you talk a little bit on the price that you came to from Geismar, you could argue that something a little multiple for WPZ to pay. Just kind of how you're thinking was coming to that price?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the multiple is always dependent on the amount of pricing risk and where you are at the peak or trough and certainly that is a buildout of the business. And so today's pricing, of course, if it's steady or the existing asset and we deserve a
componenttext: Sure. I think the multiple is always dependent on the amount of pricing risk and where you are at the peak or trough and certainly that is a buildout of the business. And so today's pricing, of course, if it's steady or the existing asset and we deserve a higher multiple for those more sure cash flows. But I think with the pricing assumption, that is our best guess that the pricing consumption nevertheless that was a peak relative to the market and so we don't think it serves such a high multiples. So a lot of as you can imagine, a lot of interesting debate among conflicts to WPZ, and it's -- the folks that support that, as well as internally here, but we think we really hit the right spot for both WMB and WPZ in that transaction.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then you touched on a little bit, but maybe talk to you on your assumption on the interest in natural gas at $3.25. It looks like closer to $4 for '13 and an ethylene, you got this big jump in '14 going from $0.50 to -- excuse me, $0.63 per kind
componenttext: Sure. And then you touched on a little bit, but maybe talk to you on your assumption on the interest in natural gas at $3.25. It looks like closer to $4 for '13 and an ethylene, you got this big jump in '14 going from $0.50 to -- excuse me, $0.63 per kind of what's driving both of those forecasts in your guidance?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: On the gas price, I'll hit that first. I think gas price yesterday is coming off about $3.90 or so up from '13. Of course, that's been moving around quite a bit. I would just tell you, we certainly hope that for the help of the industry, that's a good thi
componenttext: On the gas price, I'll hit that first. I think gas price yesterday is coming off about $3.90 or so up from '13. Of course, that's been moving around quite a bit. I would just tell you, we certainly hope that for the help of the industry, that's a good thing. But we continue to see supplies grow and in fact, our forecasted lower volume rate is not showing up currently in our growth rates continuing to grow. And so we think that a lot of the demand that we picked up over the summer obviously was very price dependent growth, and you can argue whether that price is $3.50 or $3.75 or $3.25. You can argue us to where that price that kicks total out and brings gas in, but it's certainly not $4 from our vantage point. And so, I think -- we think that, that low that we saw on the natural gas price is pretty temporary and is very price driven. So we continue to be impressed with the kind of drilling and growth around our systems as they sit here today. But we think eventually that's got to moderate and obviously that's our reaction to it. On the ethylene price, I would just tell you that the what we saw in the -- for continued to see is really a response between crude oil and ethane. As you get into '14, we're actually completely -- almost completely neutral to ethane prices, and in fact, a little bit short ethane, so if our ethane price is wrong, that will just show up in ethylene price. But really just driving that ethylene price up of CMI forecast and oil prices. So that's the best intelligence that we have based on the markets we're seeing out there.

And also with any potential over time as you invest more CapEx and get more depreciation in Canada for that 50% tax you alluded to, to come down?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say that our cash tax rate moves around a bit depending on when assets are placed in service, minimum tax, a lot of variables, it moves around a bit. I think from a planning standpoint on this slide, we have dividend illustration, we've kind of no
componenttext: I would say that our cash tax rate moves around a bit depending on when assets are placed in service, minimum tax, a lot of variables, it moves around a bit. I think from a planning standpoint on this slide, we have dividend illustration, we've kind of normalized it up about 25% rate on the distribution from WPZ. Some years are higher, some are lower, it's normalized. Therefore, to take some of the volatility out of it, I would note that when we issue equity, including in the Geismar consumption, our effective tax rate comes up because in effect to the extent that the issue to the public, there's an embedded gained here from the tax standpoint. So it's pretty complex subject. But I think the way we've modeled it here I think is generally representative with some volatility. I think you'll some years to come in sub 20 and some could approach 30. As of Canada, we've got a negative basis in our foreign assets. And so the issue there is to bring cash across the border with trigger gain, and that's a pretty substantial gain at this time.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, it comes down to tax basis in all of our international assets, and again we've got some legacy European and Venezuelan tax position. So it's a big ball that includes a lot of legacy stuff. So it's going to take some time to align that. We do h
componenttext: No. I mean, it comes down to tax basis in all of our international assets, and again we've got some legacy European and Venezuelan tax position. So it's a big ball that includes a lot of legacy stuff. So it's going to take some time to align that. We do have embedded 25% tax rate in Canada. So we are providing taxes and paying Canadian taxes at about 25% rate on Canadian income. But it's really that cash balance that we have sitting in Canada or the cash that we might generate is still working against negative tax base.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my last question, Alan, there is some questions around the changes in expected gathering with natural gas volumes. You alluded to trying to be a little conservative, especially as words switching off a bit and suggested that some of that numbers
componenttext: Okay. And my last question, Alan, there is some questions around the changes in expected gathering with natural gas volumes. You alluded to trying to be a little conservative, especially as words switching off a bit and suggested that some of that numbers may change if you're relative to the high side, maybe volumes will be greater. My question is, many producers have alternatives are saying even a $4 gas, they're not going back in turning on because there's so much more money on the liquids part of the plays that they have that there's a limited amount of capital and they just cant's see it towards dry gas. And you mentioned him in the Marcellus, that's prolific dry gas areas are using off even that's probably fairly respectable returns, some very good wells today. Can you speak to whether you really think the volumes will necessarily follow price?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a great question and one we obviously wrestled with around here on a regular basis. And I honestly think it was very dependent on producers capability, certainly not all these basins are created equal. There's quite a bit differentiation from u
componenttext: Well, it's a great question and one we obviously wrestled with around here on a regular basis. And I honestly think it was very dependent on producers capability, certainly not all these basins are created equal. There's quite a bit differentiation from unit , there's a pretty big spread in one part of the accounting versus others. And as well I would tell you that some producers are better than others at getting the cost down and as well, there's a major variability in terms of what the other options might be and what they're invested in. And so I would just say it's not as the markets that efficient in that regard. It is remarkably, to my vantage point, sometime I was marveled at how efficient it is particularly the summer, the kind of a pick up we saw with low natural gas price on the semantic. But on the producer side, it's not everybody has the same number of options or might take the rigs and some are more invested in others in getting their cost structure down in the area. And so we certainly saw that previous ownership of WTX in the Piceance where they have a very low cost structure in peons. And we certainly see that in the Marcellus with some players have a much lower cost structure and lower cash cost than others. So I would just tell you, it's pretty are able out there. And I think it's hard to drop with a broad brush. And so that's not the way we do, we do it kind of from a building it from a ground up perspective based on all the different input we get from producers in each of our areas. And so that's really how we come up with that.

componenttext: Just wanted to get your thoughts on what sort of a perfect coverage ratio for WMB and WPZ longer term? Are you seeing about, I guess you outlined in 2014, meaning 1.2x for WMB and 1.1x WPZ?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's not. I would say it's complete function of business mix and commodity prices. And the growth rate because again, as Alan mentioned earlier, in the near term we're burdened with an extraordinary growth rate. we're financing the lack of growth and that
componenttext: It's not. I would say it's complete function of business mix and commodity prices. And the growth rate because again, as Alan mentioned earlier, in the near term we're burdened with an extraordinary growth rate. we're financing the lack of growth and that means more units out, more interest expense with Lil' cash flow. But if you look at '14 and you look at the ethylene price, taken very a lot different coverage. You can move gas price and you can get much different coverage. So I think it's really a function of what you assume on prices. So the 1.23 is built off the price assumptions we have year, price and margin and all the other assumptions. So if you have your margin assumptions you'll get lower coverage, you have higher, you get higher. But again, it's going to be viable opportunity base on where we are the commodity cycle, and the number of other factors.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's Frank Ferazzi, I'll take that question. We did lose electric power in many of our transport station in New York and New Jersey and parts of Pennsylvania. But at those stations, we have a backup generation capabilities powered by natural gas, so there
componenttext: It's Frank Ferazzi, I'll take that question. We did lose electric power in many of our transport station in New York and New Jersey and parts of Pennsylvania. But at those stations, we have a backup generation capabilities powered by natural gas, so there's no disruption the flows. We do have our acidity that's located close to the water. So we anticipate that we may get some minor flooding and that we did in fact, happen. So anticipation of that, we took the facility down on Sunday. We did get in fact, water, but once the facility drive down and we pump the water away, we're not expecting the permanent damage there. No leaks on the system, no other disruptions in flow, and so I think our balance we further mark will be there. We have to remove some trees on the right of way, some were blown on but again no permanent damage in the facilities and no disruption in flow.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Rick. In the third quarter, we did see some higher in our gas pipeline. Those were driven principally by the pipeline safety act. As you know, we have to complete testing our system by the end of 2012. So we're certainly are on track to do th
componenttext: Yes, this is Rick. In the third quarter, we did see some higher in our gas pipeline. Those were driven principally by the pipeline safety act. As you know, we have to complete testing our system by the end of 2012. So we're certainly are on track to do that. But as we get near the end of that period, we did have some higher integrity and testing costs that we did see in the third quarter. And then we also saw some higher benefit cost related to our pension and our post-retirees medical expense. So those were the primary drivers I think of the lower results in the third quarter. We are on track to hit the guidance that we have given for 2012.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great question, Becca. There's been a lot of efforts around organization on that. And frankly we were responding to overhead cost as one item that came at us from the spinoff of WP X. And so cut trying to make sure that our overhead costs are in line with
componenttext: Great question, Becca. There's been a lot of efforts around organization on that. And frankly we were responding to overhead cost as one item that came at us from the spinoff of WP X. And so cut trying to make sure that our overhead costs are in line with the size of the company and the complexity of the company today. And so we are going through a process of taking out some layers of management across the organization. But as well, I would tell you very much on the positive side, we are being allowed of alignment and a lot of focus around our engineering and construction capabilities, as well as getting the customer boys from all of these areas right up to the leadership table and getting that as close to our actions as possible. So a lot of a very positive things coming out of this, what really turn to get more of the resources focused on our areas of opportunities. And when I say that I'm talking about people resources that the really focused on what our frontline opportunities whether going on our business on that word side and being able to be responsive to customers needs as this infrastructure buildup continues to really amaze us in fact the amount of demand and opportunities that are in front of us. So really trying to position the organization to be more responsive to the kind of the buildout that's ahead of us, and we continue to enjoy.

As we look at the return profile of that capital being deployed, should we be looking in sort of the return profile of a normal kind of the fee-based contract that pipeline assets or is there the opportunity to earn perhaps a significantly higher returns for that capital?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Carl, good question, and we didn't get it given all the other moving parts we've added in this earnings call, we haven't had a chance to focus very much on that. But I think we forecasted that in the past, in terms of our bullishness around the need
componenttext: Yes, Carl, good question, and we didn't get it given all the other moving parts we've added in this earnings call, we haven't had a chance to focus very much on that. But I think we forecasted that in the past, in terms of our bullishness around the need for it infrastructure as the petchem business grows of from all the NGLs just coming into the market there. And we are more convinced than ever that, that is the days and it's going to be a lot of infrastructure. We've made 3 acquisitions from pipeline that we are converting to service on here in the last 10 months or so and have been doing that fairly quietly as we want to make sure we've got the business contracted for that business. But in terms of return expectations, I can tell you that it does vary according to risk. But I would say probably on average, it's between about 14% and 20% pretax returns on those capital investments.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I will close it up here. Thank you all very much for joining us. Very excited about our future, a lot of moving parts happening in this quarter. And I want to reiterate that we are very committed to maintaining the health of WPZ as I think we
componenttext: Okay, great. I will close it up here. Thank you all very much for joining us. Very excited about our future, a lot of moving parts happening in this quarter. And I want to reiterate that we are very committed to maintaining the health of WPZ as I think we've demonstrated with the Geismar drop-down. And frankly, as we've been forecasting for quite some time, we were concerned and have been concerned about the ethane supply getting out in the head of the cracker capacity. We certainly think our Geismar expansion is very timely and is going to be able to take great advantage of new ethane supplies ahead of in the other cracker expansions. And so, but we think eventually the petchem market is going to respond to the huge amount of NGLs that producers are going after today. So we're excited to be in this space, and excited about the growth opportunities that are out for us. Really across-the-board in our business today. So really feel very good about the growth prospects that lie before us in the company, and we've got a lot of to execute on but very confident our team's ability to do that. So with that will close it up and once again, thank you very much, and good luck in your recovery if you been impacted but Hurricane Sandy. Thank you.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies' Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Porte
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Williams Companies' Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Porter, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome. As always, we thank you for your interest in Williams. As you know, yesterday afternoon, we released our financial results and posted several important items on our website, williams.com. These items include the press release
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome. As always, we thank you for your interest in Williams. 
As you know, yesterday afternoon, we released our financial results and posted several important items on our website, williams.com. These items include the press release of our results with related schedules and our analyst package; a presentation on our results and growth opportunities with related audio commentary from our President and CEO, Alan Armstrong; and an update to our quarterly data book, which contains detailed information regarding various aspects of our business.
This morning, Alan will make a few brief comments, and then we will open the discussion up for Q&A. Rory Miller is here from our Midstream business; Frank Ferazzi is here from our Gas Pipeline business; and our CFO, Don Chappel, is also available to respond to any of your questions.
In yesterday's presentation, and also in the quarterly data book, you will find an important disclaimer related to forward-looking statements. This disclaimer is important and integral to all of our remarks, and you should review it. Also included in our presentation materials are various non-GAAP measures that have been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Those reconciliation schedules appear at the back of the presentation materials.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Alan.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. First, let me wish everyone who has been affected by Hurricane Sandy, the best of luck in the recovery. As you know, given the significant disruption that occurred to the normal market activity, we decided to dela
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. First, let me wish everyone who has been affected by Hurricane Sandy, the best of luck in the recovery. As you know, given the significant disruption that occurred to the normal market activity, we decided to delay our earnings release webcast by a day. And we also know this concentrated a number of earnings calls today, so thanks a bunch for joining us this morning for this webcast amongst a very busy morning. 
Hopefully, you had a chance to listen to my prerecorded comments released yesterday afternoon. But just in case you didn't, I'll quickly hit on some key things and then we'll move on to our Q&A session. We have several really important items to communicate to you this week, starting with, of course, a review of our third quarter performance. So I'll quickly touch on the key things from that discussion.  
For the third quarter, WMB's adjusted income was up about 17% over second quarter, in spite of NGL fracs bed -- sorry, frac spreads that were about 18% lower, on average, than the already-low 2 -- second quarter amounts and the impact of Hurricane Isaac, and I'll talk about that just a little bit. 
With regard to the NGL frac spread, we saw about a 9% lower average NGL composite price, but an even higher impact from natural gas strength prices that were up about 26%, on average. So certainly, the frac spread environment that we saw on the third quarter continued to decline from what was a heavy decline from first quarter to second quarter, and so were not expecting that degree of decline into the third quarter. And again, a lot of that was impacted by gas prices moving up.  
Turning to fee-based revenues now for third quarter. This measure grew about 5% for -- year-over-year for the third quarter. And importantly, at the Midstream segment for WPZ, this grew at about 12% rate, so continued great volume growth there in our fee-based revenues. 
And just to a highlight a few of the areas that affected that, our gathering volumes in the business, such as our natural gas gathering volumes in the Midstream business, were up 17% higher from 3Q '11 to 3Q of '12. And in the eastern onshore, which is basically at our Marcellus area and the Perdido Norte, which is in the western Gulf of Mexico, we saw both of those areas' gathering volumes actually double from year-to-year.
The main driver of the 12% growth rate for -- overall for our business was the eastern G&P business, as I mentioned. And of course, one of the drivers there was the acquisition from the Caiman, which we now refer to as the hot -- Ohio Valley Midstream in our business, and that was up about $30 million between years.  
Also, there was a couple of factors that brought that 12% growth rate down and tend to lessen it. The Hurricane Isaac reduced some of our Gulf Coast fee-based revenues, and in third quarter of '11, we actually had a pretty significant contract settlement related to some of our Perdido Norte business. So on a normalized basis, we see these fee-based revenues actually growing even stronger than the 12% for WPZ Midstream. 
Most of the Hurricane Isaac impacts were cost by interruptions in third-party operations. So while we did have some immediate interruption in our offshore assets, in particular, in terms of getting things back up and running, it really was due to some downstream oil terminals and some downstream NGL pipelines that held us up a little bit longer. So we really did fair pretty well against our assets that -- but there were some assets that we're integrated with that were a little more challenge.
Hurricane Isaac also significantly impacted our results in the Midstream Canadian olefins business as Geismar had downtime that affected its production volumes, as well as some damage to a furnace, as we try to restart the plant after the hurricane. So all-in, this affected our segment profitability from about $9 million to $13 million, and about $4 million of this was treated as an assessment for adjusted settlement profit.
So that's a quick look at our third quarter drivers. But again, given the continued lower NGL commodity price environment and the Hurricane Isaac impact, we actually had a pretty good operational period here for the third quarter.
So next up, we have some important updates to our guidance for '13 and '14, from both WMB and WPZ. Included in these updates are the effect of the Geismar drop-down, which we've announced we will be closing very soon. But we've also got some other adjustments, including somewhat lower revenue growth rate assumptions for WPZ, and these are really being driven by prolonged natural gas price assumption and some of the producers' reactions that we're seeing to that as we went through our September planning process, where we've taken a lot of the input from a lot of our producers around our systems. 
And I certainly want to let you know this really is across-the-board, that we're seeing this in areas that whether -- where we may -- whether producers themselves is heavily impacted by the gas prices. So some examples of that would be areas where we call the keep-hole rights for natural gas drilling operations. And so the producers are not enjoying any of the uplift from the NGLs, and so of course, they're responding to lower natural gas prices. Those, of course, would be mostly out west, where that would occur.
We also had some response in the Gulf Coast and then, to some degree, in the northeast. But we'll get into a little bit, the northeast. The good news, I would say, in the northeast is that the activities continue there. And for the most part, the activities, particularly in Ohio Valley Midstream area, have -- really have nothing to do with either prices or with the drilling results from the resources. Actually, those are coming in a little better than we thought. It's just really a delay in terms of the activity and our ability to get infrastructure into place there quickly. 
So all in all, I would say the environment's pretty good. But I do think with our gas prices assumption at $3.25, it's in our assumptions and planning around that, we do expect continued reduction in areas that are totally dependent on just the natural gas price.
So I do want to reaffirm our plans for a strong cash dividend growth where we're expecting a 50% -- 55% higher dividend in 2012 at WMB and, as well, the 20% growth in each 2013 and 2014, which will move our dividend to $1.20, $1.44 and $1.75, respectively. 
Our stated policy of paying out WMB dividends for all of the distributions WMB receives from WPZ, less taxes, corporate interests and corporate CapEx. However, we also want investors to appreciate how committed we are at sustaining the great strength of WPZ for the long run, and of course, that's what the Geismar drop-down is all about, and it really shows the evidence of WMB's commitment to keeping WPZ healthy and making sure that the commodity hedge, the natural commodity hedge there is shared with WPZ and not just held with the WMB level. 
So in that transaction, WMB is receiving nearly 43 million new WPZ LP units related to the Geismar drop-down. Assuming the strong WPZ cash distribution growth rate included in our guidance, WMB will see a significant increase in cash distributions for WPZ. This could result, of course, in an ultimately higher dividend growth rate from what we have forecasted right now for WMB. And certainly, if the forecasted pricing environment that we have out there, particularly around ethylene prices occurs, then we would certainly be in a position to further increase the dividend at WMB. 
So a lot of questions around that as a lot of people have snapped to the fact that our cash distributions will go up significantly from that. And we've certainly been clear, but we intend to maintain the policy. And I think our response to that, and we certainly agree with that calculation, but we do have quite a bit of risk embedded in that pricing at WPZ. And so we don't really want to go out any further on that distribution being 2 years ahead of time in terms of the dividend at WMB. I do think we intend to be very sure and really work hard to maintain that -- the distribution growth rate at WPZ, however. 
And some of the things that we might respond to, if we did see a commodity collapse, it would pull us down -- pull that coverage down, of course, would be our ability to impact the GP IDRs that we receive. So we remain very committed to WPZ and help the WPZ, and we think we've got a great model. And certainly, if the pricing environment occurs, we're going to be in great shape to continue to increase that dividend at WMB even further.
Of course, at the same time, WMB will no longer enjoy 100% of the cash flow and earnings it enjoys today. And as a result, you've seen a lowering of WMB's income guidance related to the noncontrolling interest that arises in Geismar, once it's dropped into WPZ. So even though the cash flow piece of that looks stronger, the -- particularly with the capital burden being shifted over to WPZ, the earnings piece of that gets diluted by the issuance of -- to the WPZ LP unit holders. 
Additionally, as I previously mentioned, we have some other updates to our guidance for '13 and '14, including lower revenue growth rates across most of our operating areas that are exposed to natural gas prices, as I mentioned. And although we have some fairly low natural gas price assumptions in place for '13 and '14, you really should not misconstrue that we have a lack of confidence in the natural gas market. And in fact, I would tell you, we're fairly bullish about the long-term demand that we continue to see build for natural gas. But we also have been impressed with the capabilities of natural gas producers here in the U.S. to continue to lower their cost of production, and so we're balancing that. We do think it'll take some time for a lot of the big capital that's coming on to build that demand. But long term, I would tell you we're very bullish on seeing this natural gas market continue to expand.
Finally, in the prerecorded podcast, we provided additional information about exciting new develops in our Canadian and Petchem Services businesses and updates on all of our end-guidance projects, most of which are fee based that really continued to demonstrate how Williams is perfectly positioned to take advantage of this long-term super cycle as a trusted name in the development, construction and operation of exactly the types of infrastructure needed to realize the full potential for producers and end users of natural gas, NGLs and all of them. 
So with that, I'll open it up for your questions.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Faisel Khan with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Faisel Khan with Citigroup.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think I understand here the little guidance at '14. I just want to understand a little bit more, if you could, and I have a follow-up question. But on the guidance, it seems like the commodity price assumptions are roughly the same from the last time yo
componenttext: I think I understand here the little guidance at '14. I just want to understand a little bit more, if you could, and I have a follow-up question. But on the guidance, it seems like the commodity price assumptions are roughly the same from the last time you issued guidance, and so the decrease in earnings seems like a meaningful decrease in volumes. Can you elaborate a little bit more on what the volume decrease you expect in '14 versus your previous guidance? And I understand it's because of low natural gas prices.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And I would just say this, Faisel, that really what we saw -- again, how our planning process works is that we start to pull that together in September, and we take in input from all across our systems from producers planned capital for the followi
componenttext: Right. And I would just say this, Faisel, that really what we saw -- again, how our planning process works is that we start to pull that together in September, and we take in input from all across our systems from producers planned capital for the following year. Of course, it's in their best interest to have us educated on their plans as well because we've got to go build a lot of the infrastructure for those volumes. And so we've been going through that process in September, and I would just tell you that it's really across-the-board. And I would tell you if we thought as prices were going to be $4.50 or $5 in '13 and -- and then we probably would've had a different perspective on that. But with our assumption of gas prices being at $3.25 for '13, with that assumption embedded, we'd have a hard time being more bullish than the producers in terms of their capital plans. And so we really basically took the capital plans from producers. Now remember, this was -- a lot of their ideas, of course, were formed over the summer when gas prices were even softer. So if we do see gas prices rebound, we probably would see some more activity and more rigs picked up. But -- and of course, then we would have to raise our gas -- natural gas price if we believe that. And that would -- of course, would come out of the margin for both the NGLs and the olefins margin. So I think there's a pretty good balance there. But in general, I would tell you that we gather a lot of gas. And there's just a lot of areas that are exposed to natural gas price, and we're seeing drops in really all of our regions from what we had forecasted earlier in the year, based on producers' forecasts that we would have picked up in the first part of 2012.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then on the olefins business and the chemicals business. How are you guys thinking about the distributions at WPZ once you drop these assets in? I mean, will some of the distributions be a little bit more of a variable rate? Or were
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then on the olefins business and the chemicals business. How are you guys thinking about the distributions at WPZ once you drop these assets in? I mean, will some of the distributions be a little bit more of a variable rate? Or were they -- will you have some base level of free cash flows that'll be distributed to unit holders and then the rest will be kind of discretionary sort of use of capital? How are you guys thinking about this cyclical business within WPZ?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. And I would say that we do feel like we will need to maintain a coverage ratio there. Of course, one of the things that's heavily impacting our coverage ratio at PZ right now is the amount of growth and amount of equity that we've iss
componenttext: Yes, great question. And I would say that we do feel like we will need to maintain a coverage ratio there. Of course, one of the things that's heavily impacting our coverage ratio at PZ right now is the amount of growth and amount of equity that we've issued here in 2012. And so I would say that in a more normal environment, with not quite so much leverage to growth in that balance sheet, that we would expect to be seeing higher coverage ratios despite even these lower NGL prices that were -- that we saw here in the third quarter. So bottom line is we intend to maintain a coverage ratio there at WPZ and try to let the swings. Good news is that there's a lot of cash flow in WPZ, and we would expect to let that coverage absorb a lot of those swings. If that wasn't enough to absorb that, then our next move in a more dire environment would be to waive some of the GP IDR, if necessary, to maintain WPZ's health.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Bradley Olsen with Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Bradley Olsen with Tudor, Pickering.

componenttext: Just to follow up on Faisel's question about the volume growth assumptions that go into your guidance. How -- you mentioned kind of broadly lower gas volumes across geographies. Would you say that this volume change is enough to impact your longer-term 5 Bcf a day estimate in terms of gas that you handle in the Marcellus?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: It certainly could and in some areas. I would tell you the areas that are -- the drier gas are most likely to be the larger part of that impact. On OBM, I would say there might be some delays there. But currently, we're actually increasing that a little b
componenttext: It certainly could and in some areas. I would tell you the areas that are -- the drier gas are most likely to be the larger part of that impact. On OBM, I would say there might be some delays there. But currently, we're actually increasing that a little bit above, in the near term here, from what we had in our September -- sorry, in our June forecast for that. So it's really those areas that are just dependent on dry gas volumes and OBM, I would say, to the degree, that is lowered a little bit. That's going to be from just delays in getting the infrastructure and the drilling activity occurring there. But we certainly are very excited about what we continue to see in the OBM area, in terms of the producers economics and their activities and the resource there.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as far -- in the Midstream side of the business at WPZ, it looked like that the OpEx, which had ticked up in the second quarter, was kind of flat sequentially. And I was wondering if there are items in there which are transitory in nature
componenttext: Okay, great. And as far -- in the Midstream side of the business at WPZ, it looked like that the OpEx, which had ticked up in the second quarter, was kind of flat sequentially. componenttext: Brad, this is Rory. I'd say for the near term out across Midstream on operating expenses, we're probably pretty flat with '12. And so in terms of thinking about a run rate -- now that's probably a comment that I'm making for '13. But we're expecting to be fairly flat with '12 for '13, and then after that, there maybe some growth.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one last question. headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Don. I could just mention that the assets that we announced, the petrochemical assets we acquired from Exxon, will be owned at the Williams level for the time being. We felt that Williams had more financial capacity to hold those assets while they
componenttext: This is Don. I could just mention that the assets that we announced, the petrochemical assets we acquired from Exxon, will be owned at the Williams level for the time being. We felt that Williams had more financial capacity to hold those assets while they're being developed than PZ did, given the already large array of growth opportunities that PZ was holding. So that was the primary reason we moved that to Williams rather than WPZ. But that remains a drop-down opportunity that PZ will likely enjoy in the future day.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ted Durbin with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ted Durbin with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Maybe just thinking about the commodity exposure here at the WMB level and the increased investments in Canada. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about the mix of maybe adding more commodity sensitivity with those additional investments rather than -
componenttext: Maybe just thinking about the commodity exposure here at the WMB level and the increased investments in Canada. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about the mix of maybe adding more commodity sensitivity with those additional investments rather than -- and kind of how you're thinking about what the cash otherwise you could do if there's tax issues with bringing it back, and maybe that's part of the reason why you're driving more investments in Canada.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just -- this is Don again. I would say that, again, for us to bring back $500 million, our cash tax rate to be about 50%. So about $250 million of that would be paid to the IRS. So that's a pretty -- a lot of value leakage. And the good news is we have so
componenttext: Just -- this is Don again. I would say that, again, for us to bring back $500 million, our cash tax rate to be about 50%. So about $250 million of that would be paid to the IRS. So that's a pretty -- a lot of value leakage. And the good news is we have some opportunities in Canada that we think are very strong with very high rates of returns. So if we look at that versus the opportunities here at the U.S., we just see, despite the fact there's some commodity volatility, just have higher hurdle rate on those projects, such that even in a low-commodity price environment, there's still very attractive investments. And in a more of an expected case, it's very strong. And when you compare that to paying all that cash tax and bringing it back and investing in an opportunity here in the U.S., it's the Canadian investment, despite the fact that it's in commodity-sensitive businesses that tends to be something that we're interested in. I think the one area that we're exploring is PDH. And again, we think that propane in Canada is likely to be under tremendous pressure, and the margins on that business will likely be very strong.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would add to that on the -- this is Alan. I would add to that as  that the prints in some CNRL business, there's ethane contract that supports that. It does have a floor for the ethane. That's at a cost of service pricing for the ethane. So there is som
componenttext: I would add to that on the -- this is Alan. I would add to that as  that the prints in some CNRL business, there's ethane contract that supports that. It does have a floor for the ethane. That's at a cost of service pricing for the ethane. So there is some contractual support for that risk that we're taking in that expansion up there, for both the new ethane capital that we're investing, as well as the CNRL expansion.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great, got it. That's great. And can you talk a little bit on the price that you came to for Geismar? It's -- you could argue it's somewhat within a low multiple for WPZ to pay. Just kind of how you're thinking was coming to that price.
componenttext: Great, got it. That's great. And can you talk a little bit on the price that you came to for Geismar? It's -- you could argue it's somewhat within a low multiple for WPZ to pay. Just kind of how you're thinking was coming to that price.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the multiple is always dependent on the amount of pricing risk and where you are, at a peak or a trough, and certainly, that is a buildout of a business. And so today's pricing, of course, if it was a steady, already-existing asset that didn
componenttext: Sure. I think the multiple is always dependent on the amount of pricing risk and where you are, at a peak or a trough, and certainly, that is a buildout of a business. And so today's pricing, of course, if it was a steady, already-existing asset that didn't have a lot of growth on it would deserve a higher multiple for those more sure cash flows. But I think with the pricing assumption, we -- that is our best guess at the pricing assumption that's out there. But nevertheless, that is a peak relative to the market, and so we don't think we deserve such a high multiple. So a lot of -- as you can imagine, a lot of interesting debate amongst conflicts committee to WPZ, and it's -- the folks that support that, as well as internally here. But we think we really hit the right spot, for both WMB and WPZ, in that transaction.

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then you touched on it a little bit. But maybe talk through a little bit more of your assumptions on the price forecast. I'm particularly interested in natural gas at $3.25. It looks like the forward curve is closer to $4 for '13. And then on et
componenttext: Sure. And then you touched on it a little bit. But maybe talk through a little bit more of your assumptions on the price forecast. I'm particularly interested in natural gas at $3.25. It looks like the forward curve is closer to $4 for '13. And then on ethylene, you got this big jump in '14 going from $0.50 a pound, excuse me, to $0.63. Kind of what's driving both of those forecasts in your guidance?

headline: Williams Companies, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the gas price, I'll hit that first. I think gas price yesterday is coming off of a year about $3.90 or so, up for '13, and of course, that's been moving around quite a bit. I would just tell you, we've certainly hope that. I think for the help of
componenttext: Sure. On the gas price, I'll hit that first. I think gas price yesterday is coming off of a year about $3.90 or so, up for '13, and of course, that's been moving around quite a bit. I would just tell you, we've certainly hope that. I think for the help of the industry, that's a good thing. But we continue to see supplies grow. And in fact, our forecast of lower volume rate is not showing up currently in our growth rates. It's continuing to grow. And so we think that a lot of the demand that we picked up over the summer, obviously, was very price-dependent growth, and you can argue whether that price is $3.50 or $3.75 or $3.25. You can argue as to where that price that kicks coal out and brings gas in, but it's certainly not $4 from our vantage point. And so I think -- we think that, that low that we saw in the natural gas price is pretty temporary and is very price driven. So we continue to be impressed with the kind of drilling and growth around our systems as we sit here today. But we think, eventually, that's got to moderate, and obviously, that's the -- our reaction to it. On the ethylene price, I would just tell you that the -- what we saw in the -- what we continue to see is really a response to -- between crude oil and ethane. As you get into '14, we're actually completely -- or almost completely neutral to ethane prices and, in fact, a little bit short ethane. So if our ethane price is wrong, that'll just show up in ethylene price, but really just driving that ethylene price off of CMAI forecast and oil prices then. So that's the best intelligence that we have based on the markets that we're seeing out there.
